LTTextBox.text: GEOPHYSICS
4.1.  Magnetics
Apex Minerals NL organised for an aeromagnetic survey to be flown over their Windimurra project
in  September-October  2002.  The  area  covering  the  portion  of  the  lease  to  be  relinquished  was
flown at 200m line spacing and at a height of 35m above ground level. The data from the portion to
be relinquished is tabulated in Appendix 1 and depicted in Figure 4.
Map Grid of Australia 1994 (MGA94)
Zone 50
Australian Height Datum (AHD)
Isogal 1984/ IGSN 71
4.2.  Gravity
Haines Surveys Pty Ltd carried out a regional GPS gravity survey over the Windimurra project in
March 2004. The data was collected with a station spacing of 500m and a line spacing of either
500m or 1,000m. A total of 100 stations were collected on the area to be relinquished. The station
locations are depicted in Figure 5 and the results in Figure 6. The following datums were used:
Horizontal Datum:  Geocentric Datum of Australia 1994 (GDA94)
Vertical Datum:
Gravity Datum:
Survey and Gravity Base Stations
Base  stations  were  established  in  all  the  survey  areas  in  positions  to  provide  good  VHF  radio
coverage for the RTK system. The bases were designated as 2004.2901, 2004.2902, 2004.2903,
and 2004.2904. All bases were marked with a short star picket driven flush with the natural surface
and witnessed by a long star picket within 0.3m of the ground mark standing about 1m tall. Two
aluminium  tags  are  attached  to  each  base  with  the  inscription  "Haines  Surveys"  and  "Gravity
2004.2901” etcetera. All details of the Survey and Gravity base stations are tabulated in Appendix
2. Subsidiary bases were located within 5 minutes drive of each main base to provide a backup
base  station  in  case  loop  ties  to  the  main  base  were  poor.  These  are  not  marked  but  the
approximate coordinates (+/- 10m) listed in the table in Appendix 2 define their locations. A further
subsidiary gravity base (2004.2999) was located at Narndee Station. This is also not marked but
approximate coordinates (+/- 5m) are listed in the table.
Survey and Gravity Control
Horizontal  and  vertical  control  for  2004.2901,  2004.2902,  2004.2903  and  2004,2904  has  been
established using the AUSPOS online GPS processing service provided by Geoscience Australia.
This  method  provides  control  within  the  GDA94  Datum  to  within  +/-  5  cm.  Gravity  control  for
2004.2901 base station and the subsidiary base 2004.2999 at Narndee Station was established on
the  Australian  Fundamental  Gravity  Network  (Isogal 1984 / IGSN 71) using two A-B-A ties from
Australian  Geological  Survey  Office  (AGSO)  gravity  station  6792.0121,  Mount  Magnet  A/S
Terminal.  The  value  for  6792.0121  was  obtained  from  Geoscience  Australia.  Gravity  control  for
2004.2902,  2004.2903  and  2004.2904  was  established  by  repeated  loop  closures  opening  and
closing on 2004.2999.
Control information is tabulated in Appendix 2.
Gravity Observations
Gravity  measurements  have  been  made  using  Scintrex  CG3  Autograv  instruments.  Instrument
numbers 310217, 610360 and 908474 were used on this project. Readings of 120 seconds were
taken at base stations. Readings of 40 seconds were taken at all other gravity survey points. Base
station readings were taken at the beginning of the day and at the end of the day’s fieldwork. The
CG3 instrument applies an instrument drift correction to its final gravity reading. Any residual drifts
between base station readings are corrected by the gravity post processing software.
Windimurra Partial Surrender Report E59/907
